title.narrative: Amplifying the voices of women in the ME

description.narrative:
Although women in the MENA region are currently suffering from a backlash in the area of womens rights, the current uprisings and transitions taking place in that region provide an invaluable window of opportunity for gender equality. To utilize this opportunity it is extremely important that women effectively participate in decision-making and peace and transition processes. Three Dutch applicants will do so by strengthening the capacities of CSOs at national level (Iraq, OPT, Syria and Yemen) and regional level; challenging attitudes, idea and beliefs on womens participation and linking national results and learning to regional and global level and vice versa. By combining their specific strengths in different areas they will contribute to strengthening womens voices, and socialacceptance thereof, for sustainable conflict transformation through application of UN1325 as a positive and dynamic tool for participatory peace building.
The programme aims to contribute to the creation of an enabling environment for womens leadership and political participation, in order to promote more inclusive, just and sustainable peace, recovery and reconstruction processes, by strengthening womens voices in the political arena, in particular in the area of peace and security, and social acceptance of their (womens) roles, for sustainable conflict transformation in the MENA region.
The specific program objective is strengthening understandingand capacities of stakeholders on UN1325 at global, regional level and atnational level in Yemen, OPT, Iraq and Syria and piloting innovative techniques altering attitudes and believes to create acceptance of gender equality and womens rights. Expected results include: 1. A contribution to increased accountability and monitoring of the integration of peace, justice and disarmament from a gender perspective into the work and output of the relevant processes of the Human Rights, WPS and disarmament systems, in relation to the MENA region (By monitoring of all Human Rights Council and Security Council sessions; By submission of statements and organisation of side-events; By support to the NGO reporting to the UPR and the Treaty Body system – through information, webinars and guidelines developed for NGO reporting including thenew general recommendation on WPS to CEDAW; 2. Linkages between women, peace and security perspectives and UN1325, and lobby and advocacy on peace <(>&<)> human security towards the League of Arab States; 3 . At least 25civil society representatives have enhanced understanding of state accountability, gendered peace and security, with the inclusion of a masculinities perspective; (By building the capacity of concerned organisations, individuals and experts on gender-sensitive active nonviolence (with inclusion of a masculinities perspective) and the WPS agenda; By linking and learning from each othens (national) contexts and experiences, and bringing them together at the regional level). 4. At least 10 women - and peace organisations have advanced capacity, outreach and influence of womens and peace organisations to address WPS issues at the national and local levels (By improving the ability of civil society organisations to link women at grassroots level to women in positions of representation,either at national level or at the most relevant local/regional level depending on country context; By placing womens participation as central to peace-building and conflict transformation; By coalition building and networking between organisations working towards a gender just peace from either a conflict transformation or womens rights angle). 5. The understanding and support of both womenand men targeted by the program have increased for womens participation in peace and security processes with 10%;(By supporting potential change makers to effectively undertake advocacy roles; By positioning women as strategists in the decision-making process, togo beyond a symbolic presence in peace processes and to ensure that womens concerns are taken from grassroots to national level; Byaltering patriarchal and conservative interpretations of gender roles through testing innovative approaches and techniques; By rolling out a number of successful pilots that have already taken place in the MENA region)

participating-org.narrative:
The Culture and Free Thought Association is a community-based organization that was established in 1991 by opening Al Shruq Wal Amal Center for children between the ages of 6 to 12. CFTA came as a response to the socio-political situation in 1991 and especially its effect on women and children. The programs initiated at the time aimed at providing secure places for children where they could get social and psychological support as well as enjoy recreational activities. CFTA’s program was the first of its kind in the Gaza Strip and still is unique especially with the quality of services provided to the target groups. CFTA was initiated by 5 women who atthe time represented 5 different political parties who are all members of the PLO. In 1991, CFTA was an initiative, even the name was not yet assigned for the association, and it was like a movement that is advocating for better change in the life of children and women. The work of CFTA grew and expanded every year. By 1995, CFTA was running 4 centres: Shruq Wal Amal Center, Bunat Il Ghad for teenagers, the Women Health Center and the Gaza Women’s Loan Fund. The team expanded from 13 staff to 25 employees. It was in 1996when CFTA moved from being a community initiative to being an organisation. It was registered with the Ministry of Interior in Gazaand new management, account and administrative system started to build up to become today one of the most professional organizations in Gaza Strip.
Today, in 2010, CFTA runs 8 different programs: 2 children centres One teenagers/ adolescents centre T wo women centres Youth/ cultural program Mentoring program And a network for CBOs from the south
CFTA 1991 to 2008 1991: Opening of Al Shruq Wal Amal Center 1993: Opening of Bunat Il Ghad Center 1995: Opening of both the Women's Health Center and Gaza Women's Loan Fund 1997: Opening of the Palestinian Cultural Center 2000: Start of the Youth program 2006: Initiation of the Wessal Network 2007: Opening of Al Nawwar Center
Mission: The Culture and Free Thought Association is a Palestinian pioneering institution which always seeks to concentrate on and further the values of civil society through implementing a set of programs and activities aimed at advancing societal awareness in all relevant fields; including the cultural, sociological, recreational, educational, health and economic fields, and, through its activities and projects, to provide vital services to society’s children, youth and women. CFTA, in accomplishing its mission, relies on a highly-qualified and creative staff, on its trust in the ability of the society it serves, and on its close relationship with such society.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
